Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: An Ethnographic Study of Science, Industry, and Food Enhancement

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is an ethnographic study of the organic chemists and flavorists who develop, manufacture, and market synthetic flavorings. Research will involve twelve months of multi-sited fieldwork in the United States and include from participant observation and 20-35 in-depth qualitative interviews.

The research will result in a dissertation and trained professional. The findings should be of value to food scientists and the food industry.

ProgramReference.Text: SOC STUDIES OF SCI, ENG & TECH

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ana Maria Ulloa has completed research for her dissertation "Accounting for Flavor: An Ethnographic Study of Science, Industry, and Gastronomy" supported by the NSF Dissertation Grant. During her funding period, she spent 14 months at smell and taste laboratories, flavor companies, and high-end restaurants in the United States and Spain. In particular she conducted fieldwork at Monell Chemical Senses Center in Philadelphia, Givaudan Iberica in Sant Celoni, Spain, and El Celler de Can Roca in Girona, Spain. All leading institutions and organizations in their respective fields. As an antropologist of food, she was interested in understanding how is flavor studied by scientists, flavorists, and chefs, and how is ultimately designed for divergent eating experiences of mass consumption and fine dining. She has specifically focused on the methods employed by different experts for communicating and measuring the multisensory and subjective experience of flavor.  

As a participant observer and intern at these institutions, Ana Maria accomplished the goals of her research and presented the project to different audiences from academia, industry and culinary arts. Alongside her research, she collaborated with chefs and flavorists in thinking about diversity and innovation in flavor creation. She also collaborated with the staff of El Celler de Can Roca, a restaurant devoted to vanguard cooking and considered among the best of the world, in thinking about sensory education for cooks, waiters, and sommeliers. A publication is expected to come out as a result of this collaboration. The data collected observing the daily operations of scientists, flavorists, and chefs will serve as empirical basis for an argument she is constructing about current relations among science, industry and culinary arts.

The dissertation will be completed in 2016 and will be an important contribution to the fields of anthropology of food and the senses, as well as for social studies of science and technology beacuse it looks at flavor as an object of scientific study and technological intervention.
